data.text:
From critically acclaimed dramas to thought-provoking social commentaries, Sudhir Mishra has made a name for himself in the world of cinema. In this roundup article, we explore the impressive portfolio of Sudhir Mishra’s movies and highlight the unique qualities that make his directorial work stand out. < Get ready to dive into the world of Mishra’s filmmaking genius, where storytelling meets artistry and leaves a lasting impression.

As an Amazon Associate I earn from qualifying purchases.

1. Jaane Bhi Do Yaaro (1983)

In a world where corruption and scandalous activities rule the rich, two unsuspecting photographers find themselves at the epicenter of it all. Hired by a magazine editor to expose the truth, they stumble upon the nefarious activities of a builder, and inadvertently capture a chilling murder scene.

2. Mohan Joshi Hazir Ho! (1984)

“Mohan Joshi Hazir Ho! “ (1984) is a powerful drama that takes us on a journey of unwavering dignity and moral values. Directed by Saeed Akhtar Mirza, this poignant film revolves around an elderly couple, Mohan Joshi (Bhisham Sahni) and his wife, who find themselves fighting their landlord, Raghav (Amjad Khan), over the maintenance of their dilapidated apartment.

3. Khamosh (1986)

In the shadowy realm of Bollywood comes “Khamosh, “ a chilling blend of mystery and dark comedy that will keep you on edge. When an aspiring starlet is brutally murdered on the set of a glamorous film, the stage is set for an intense investigation that will expose the hidden corners of India’s entertainment industry. The seasoned detective on the case will probe the cast and crew, discovering the seamy underbelly of ambition, greed, and deceit.

4. Main Zinda Hoon (1988)

Main Zinda Hoon, released in 1988, is a powerful Indian drama film that explores the challenges and triumphs of a middle-class housewife. When her husband abandons the family, the resilient protagonist must step up to become the sole breadwinner.

5. Dharavi (1992)

“Dharavi, “ set in the bustling city of Bombay, India, follows the life of Rajkaran, a resident of the world’s largest slum. Struggling to make ends meet, Rajkaran works diligently to start his own business. However, fate turns against him, leaving him with nothing but regret and solitude.

6. Maya (1993)

Experience an intriguing tale of love, betrayal, and tragedy as Ketan Mehta’s 1993 movie “Maya” unfolds. Starring Deepa Sahi, Farooq Shaikh, and Raj Babbar, this suspenseful drama is a captivating exploration into the destructive paths of an insatiable hunger for romance. An enthralling narrative of marriage and relationships unfolds, with a clever nonlinear timeline. “Maya” takes the audience on an emotional journey, where the titular character’s unquenchable thirst for multiple romantic interests leads to heartbreaking consequences. As the plot unfolds, a police investigation ensues, leaving viewers on the edge of their seats. An engaging exploration of love, betrayal, and the consequences of our actions, the film transports you into an intriguing world of drama, mystery, and romance. Directed by Ketan Mehta, and written by Gustave Flaubert, Sitanshu Yashaschandra, and Mehta, “Maya” presents a complex portrayal of love, loyalty, and the devastating impact of deceit. Join the characters as they navigate the world of extramarital affairs and dysfunctional marriages, ultimately discovering the profound implications of their decisions. “Maya” is a fascinating blend of Hindi cinema, blending elements from France, the UK, and India, making it a must-watch for fans of romantic dramas. This film has achieved one win across various awards categories and boasts a cast with powerful performances, all working together to create a gripping narrative that leaves viewers questioning the true nature of love and relationships. Don’t miss the chance to experience the captivating world of “Maya”, where love, tragedy, and the consequences of our choices converge in this enthralling dramatic exploration.

7. 1942: A Love Story (1994)

“1942: A Love Story” transports viewers back in time to the tumultuous 1940s, where a young Indian couple from affluent backgrounds find themselves entangled in the Indian revolutionary movement against their own families, who are under the control of a ruthless British general. This epic tale of love and rebellion tackles themes of family dynamics, loyalty, and the fight for freedom. The film’s impressive cast, including Anil Kapoor, Jackie Shroff, and Manisha Koirala, delivers a heart-wrenching performance that leaves a lasting impact.

8. Is Raat Ki Subah Nahin (1996)

In the gripping neo-noir thriller “Is Raat Ki Subah Nahin” (1996), Ramanbhai, the criminal don of Bombay, rules his city with an iron fist. When his rival Vilas Pandey challenges his reign, a tense game of cat and mouse ensues. Ramanbhai’s attempts to woo a woman, Pooja, are thwarted by Pooja’s boyfriend, Aditya, leading to a web of deceit, vengeance, and betrayal.

9. The Death Sentence: Mrityu Dand (1997)

“The Death Sentence: Mrityu Dand” is a gripping action-drama film released in 1997. Set against the backdrop of a patriarchal society, this powerful movie revolves around three courageous women who have the audacity to stand up and defy the norms. The film delves into the heart of the struggle of these women, as they boldly challenge the status quo, speaking their minds and threatening to shake the very foundations of society.

10. Rahul (2001)

“Rahul” explores the tumultuous world of family relationships and the challenges faced by Mira and Akash, who defy tradition to be married and have a child. When their child, Rahul, is born, their happiness is short-lived as a bitter legal battle ensues. Delving into the complexities of child custody, the film follows the couple’s struggle, highlighting the drama and strife that can arise from seemingly simple decisions.

11. Hazaaron Khwaishein Aisi (2003)

Hazaaron Khwaishein Aisi, an engrossing drama set amidst the turbulent times of Indian Emergency in 1975, captures the essence of friendship as it charts the lives of three friends whose existence is forever altered by the events that unfold. The film offers a raw and honest portrayal of the struggles faced during that era, creating a rich tapestry of emotions against the backdrop of the 1970s. With an ensemble cast led by Kay Kay Menon, Shiney Ahuja, and Chitrangda Singh, this compelling narrative is sure to resonate with viewers and leave a lasting impact.

12. Paanch (2003)

Paanch, released in 2003, is a gripping crime thriller that revolves around four friends whose kidnapping plot takes a dark and tragic turn. When they attempt to abduct their own friend, unintended consequences lead to the accidental killing of their target. The film, written and directed by Anurag Kashyap, presents a chilling and witty portrayal of the complexities in friendships and loyalty in the face of danger.

“Chameli, “ directed by Sudhir Mishra, is a thought-provoking drama that delves into the complexities of human connections. Set against the backdrop of a rainy night, an investment banker unexpectedly finds solace in the company of a prostitute.

Calcutta Mail, a riveting drama set in a city fraught with political intrigue, follows journalist Avinash as he finds himself targeted for his unyielding quest for the truth. The film masterfully weaves together action, drama, and mystery, creating a thrilling narrative that will leave audiences on the edge of their seats.

Kal: Yesterday and Tomorrow weaves a gripping tale of love, betrayal, and the unexpected twists of fate. Directed and written by Ruchi Narain, the film follows the lives of Bhavna Dayal and Maya Jalan, two wealthy young women who were once inseparable and now find themselves entangled in a web of deception.

Experience the enchanting world of glamour and love in the 2007 Hindi-language drama, Khoya Khoya Chand. Directed by Sudhir Mishra, this captivating film follows the story of Zafar, a young and rebellious writer, as he moves to Mumbai to pursue his dreams in the Bollywood film industry.

17. Traffic Signal (2007)

“Traffic Signal” is a hard-hitting Indian film directed by Madhur Bhandarkar, delving into the multimillion-dollar begging industry in the nation. This gripping drama stands out among its contemporaries like “Page 3”, “Corporate”, “Chandni Bar”, and “Fashion”. The film brings to the forefront the truth that lies behind the traffic signals in India and offers a shocking revelation about the begging mafia.

“Journey Beyond Borders: Discovering the Magic of Indian Ocean” is a captivating 2008 documentary film that delves into the lives and music of India’s leading contemporary music band. This riveting film follows the extraordinary journey of Indian Ocean, a band that has indelibly marked their presence on India’s music landscape.

19. Mumbai Cutting (2008)

Mumbai Cutting, a riveting drama from 2008, offers an extraordinary exploration of the city through the lens of eleven talented directors. Each director contributes a unique story, weaving together a tapestry of compelling narratives that capture the essence of urban life in Mumbai. The film features a star-studded ensemble cast, including Meer Asad Ali, Raj Singh Arora, and Arjan Bajwa, delivering powerful performances that enhance the film’s impact.

20. Raat Gayi, Baat Gayi? (2009)

“Raat Gayi, Baat Gayi? “ is a captivating comedy-drama from India that follows a married man as he tries to piece together the events of a wild party, seeking answers from his friends. With a star-studded cast, including Aamir Bashir, Anil Chaudhary, and Makrand Deshpande, and directed by Saurabh Shukla, this film offers a mix of heartfelt humor and emotional depth.

21. Tera Kya Hoga Johnny (2009)

“Tera Kya Hoga Johnny” is a gripping crime drama that delves into the dark underbelly of the city, where an innocent boy’s life takes an unexpected turn. Johnny, played by Neil Nitin Mukesh, is a coffee vendor by day, but after being pushed to his limits, he becomes involved in a robbery. Set against the backdrop of the bustling city, this thrilling movie explores themes of love, adultery, and the corrupting influence of power.

“Yeh Saali Zindagi” is a gripping crime drama that takes you deep into the underbelly of India’s criminal world. The story revolves around a gangster’s life, filled with kidnapping, sexual tension, and profanity.

25. 404: Error Not Found (2011)

“404: Error Not Found” is a gripping psychological thriller that takes a chilling turn when a bright young student starts hallucinating after moving into a mysterious room where a previous tenant committed suicide. The student discovers he has inherited strange supernatural powers, plunging him into a terrifying downward spiral as he grapples with the horrifying legacy of the room’s haunted past. This spine-tingling drama, under the direction of Prawaal Raman, is a suspenseful journey into the depths of the human psyche and the supernatural forces that may lie within.

26. Cinema Is Everywhere (2011)

“Cinema Is Everywhere” (2011) delves into the captivating and far-reaching impact of cinema on film fans and aspiring artists across the globe. This documentary offers an intriguing glimpse into the world of movies through three unique narratives, each representing different perspectives and challenges encountered in the film industry. In Mumbai’s bustling environment, a dedicated young actress strives to make her mark in the famed Bollywood world.

“Inkaar” is a gripping drama that explores the dark underbelly of corporate power struggles. Set in a renowned advertising agency, the film follows the intense rivalry between Rahul Verma, the confident CEO, and Maya Luthra, his ambitious protégée. Tensions spiral when Maya accuses Rahul of sexual harassment, a claim that threatens to dismantle their careers and relationships.

From India, the land of vibrant colors, rich history, and diverse cultures comes “I Am Offended” (2015). A revealing documentary, it unveils the untapped world of stand-up comedy in India and the humorous landscape of contemporary Indian humor.

29. Ebar Shabor (2015)

Ebar Shabor, released in 2015, is a crime thriller that takes the audience on a mysterious journey with master detective Shabor Dasgupta (played by Saswata Chatterjee). The story revolves around the gruesome murder of Mitali Ghosh (Swastika Mukherjee), a woman whose past was far from clean. As the investigation unfolds, Detective Dasgupta must navigate through a web of deception and intrigue, hoping to uncover the true victim of the savage crime.

Serious Men is a riveting drama-comedy that unfolds the struggles of a father, played by the versatile Nawazuddin Siddiqui, dealing with the societal pressure of being ‘under-privileged’. Desperate to provide for his family, he takes advantage of his son’s sudden fame as a child prodigy, portrayed by the talented Aakshath Das.

32. Afwaah (2023)

“Afwaah” is an enthralling drama-thriller film that hits the screens in 2023, showcasing the life of an advertising professional and a political heiress who find their lives turned upside down by a viral social media rumour. The film, co-produced by Benaras Mediaworks and T-Series, is directed by Sudhir Mishra and written by Apurva Dhar Badgaiyan, Shiva Shankar Bajpai, and Nisarg Mehta. “Afwaah” stars Bhumi Pednekar, Nawazuddin Siddiqui, and Sumeet Vyas.
